page.title: 02Employment Game Keepers
page.content: The Eagle Hall Gamekeeper looks after four thousand pheasants each year.When wild birds start laying in April eggs are collected three or four times a day.The eggs are stored and placed in incubators once a week.Here they stay for three weeks and for the last four days are transfered to the hatchers. When the chicks hatch they are moved to large sheds where they are put under gas or electric heaters to keep them warm.Here they stay for five or six weeks before they are released into The Great Low Wood at Eagle Hall. While hatching is taking place in the Spring and early Summer vermin such as foxes, rats, stoats and weasles have to be caught.These preditors if left unchecked would eat the young pheasant chicks when they were released into the wild.
